intro: Rubus glandulosus var. arabicus, commonly known as the Arabian raspberry, is a shrub native to arid and semi-arid regions of the Middle East and North Africa. It typically grows to a height of 1–2 meters and has thorny stems covered in glandular hairs. The plant produces small, red berries that are edible and have a tart flavor, often used in local cuisines. Its leaves are trifoliate, with serrated edges, and it thrives in well-drained soils. The species is adapted to withstand high temperatures and low rainfall, making it a resilient plant in its native habitat.
